ARTICLE

Power-dependent upconversion quantum yield of NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+
nano- and micrometer-sized particles – Measurements and simulations
Martin Kaiser, a Christian Würth, a Marco Kraft, a Iko Hyppänen, b Tero Soukka, b and Ute ReschGenger a,*
Photophysical studies of nonlinear lanthanide-doped photon upconverting nanoparticles (UCNP) increasingly used in biophotonics and photovoltaics require absolute measurements of excitation power density (P)-dependent upconversion luminescence (UCL) and luminescence quantum yields (UC) for quantifying material performance, UCL deactivation pathways, and possible enhancement factors. We present here the P-dependence of UCL spectra, UC , and slope factors of the different emission bands of representative 25 nm-sized oleate-capped -NaYF4:Yb 3+: 17 %, Er3+: 3% UCNP dispersed in toluene and as powder as well as UC of 3 µm-sized upconversion particles (UCP), all measured with a newly designed integrating sphere setup, enabling controlled variation of P over four orders of magnitude. This includes quantifying the influence of the beam shape on measured UC and comparison of experimental UC with simulations utilizing the balancing power density model of the Andersson-Engels group and simulated UC of UCP from the Berry group, underpinned by closely matching decay kinetics of our UC material. We obtained a maximum UC of 10.5 % for UCµP and UC of 0.6 % and 2.1 % for dispersed and solid UCNPs, respectively. Our results suggest an overestimation of the contribution of the purple and an underestimation of that of the red emission of -NaYF4:Yb 3+, Er3+: microparticles by the simulations of the Berry group. Moreover, our measurements can be used as guideline to absolute determinations of UCL and UC.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Lanthanide-doped photon upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) are an emerging class of multiphotonic reporters for fluorescence assays and bioimaging studies as well as functional materials for sub-bandgap energy harvesting in photovoltaics, and security printing which reveal a multitude of sharp luminescence bands in the ultraviolet (UV), visible (vis), and near-infrared (NIR) upon sequential absorption of two or more NIR photons. 1-13 Although UCNP can be meanwhile tuned in crystal size, phase, and emission color through refined synthetic procedures, 14 full exploitation of their potential is hampered by the need to improve their brightness. This requires strategies to brighter UCNP utilizing sophisticated core-shell architectures, plasmonic structures, and dye sensitization 15-18 and tools to reliably characterize and quantify the excitation power density (P) dependent luminescence of UCNPs, especially their photoluminescence quantum yields (), i.e., the ratio of the number of emitted
(Nem) to absorbed photons (Nabs), 19-22 see eq. 1. For upconversion (UC) materials, UC is defined as ratio of the number of emitted photons Nem with a wavelength em < abs, obtained from integral emission intensities of all UC emission bands (except for sensitizer luminescence), and Nabs, see eq. 2. 19, 20, 23-25
For arbitrary P, UC(P) can be simulated with a
simplified rate equation model of a two level-emitter system (eq. 4 developed by the Andersson-Engels group), 26 using a) UC,sat, obtained from converging of UC(P) at high P and b) the balancing power density Pbalance, where UC(Pbalance) equals UC,sat/2. This approach is strictly only valid for a purely biphotonic emission like the green or the 800 nm luminescence in Yb 3+/ Er 3+ and Yb 3+ /Tm 3+ systems, respectively, and monodisperse and uniform particles (eq. 3). Also other UC luminescence (UCL) features like the photonic nature or slope factor n (eq. 4), which provides the number of photons required to populate a certain emissive electronic state, 27 are P-dependent. This results in a decrease of n with increasing P, for P exceeding a certain material-, size-, and matrixdependent level. 26, 27 This must be considered for mechanistic studies.
𝜙 = 𝑁em/𝑁abs (eq. 1)
𝜙UC(𝑃) = 𝑁em/𝑁abs, for em < abs (eq. 2)
𝜙UC(𝑃) = 𝜙UC,sat /( 𝑃balance
𝑃 + 1), (eq. 3)

sections.heading: ARTICLE Nanoscale
sections.text:
2 | Nanoscale., 2017, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
for a biphotonic process
𝐼UC~𝑃 𝑛 , for low P (eq. 4)
Nevertheless, often only single UC values for a certain, often unknown P are reported to emphasize the performance of a new UC material and data comparability is hampered by different excitation sources (different excitation wavelengths), excitation geometries, beam profiles (BPs), and P. The reliability of often performed relative UC determinations or determinations of enhancement factors with a spectrofluorometer 28 or an integrating sphere, using an organic dye like IR26 29 or another UC material 30 as reference has not yet been confirmed. The recently recognized need for quantitative UCL measurements has turned the determination of UC and saturated UC (UC,sat) one of the ultimate cornerstones of UC nanotechnology 5 to identify optimum strategies to brighter UCNP. This has meanwhile triggered an increasing number of reports on absolute UC measurements, 31-41 with the highest UC values of Yb 3+ ,Er 3+ - based systems obtained so far being 7.8 % for a µm-sized NaYF4:Yb 3+ ,Er 3+ powder at P of 22 Wcm -2 , 38 and 5 % for 40 nmsized core-shell LiLuF4:Yb 3+ ,Er 3+ particles dispersed in hexane at P of 127 Wcm -2 , 39 respectively, but detailed descriptions of instrument design and actual performance of UC measurements are commonly missing. Furthermore, P is commonly at best varied over up to two orders of magnitude, which is often not sufficient for UC saturation. To close this gap, we assess here different strategies for the absolute determination of P-dependent UCL with a custom designed integrating sphere setup representatively for high quality monodisperse 25 nm-sized oleate-capped -NaYF4:Er 3+ : 3%, Yb 3+ :17 % particles dispersed in toluene and as powder as well as commercial 3 µm-sized -NaYF4:Er 3+ : 2.2 %, Yb 3+ :21.4 % particles (UCµP). The latter, used as representative bulk material, 42 were chosen to closely match particles characterized by van Veggel 32
in his pioneering work on UC
measurements of dispersed UCNP and UCµP studied by the Berry group. 23 Our experimental results are compared with simulations utilizing the balancing power density/saturation model 26 and simulated UC of UCµP from the Berry group. 23 Additionally, P-dependent intensity contributions of the green (520, 540 nm, 2 H11/2, 4 S3/2 → 4 I15/2), red (655 nm, 4 F9/2 → 4 I15/2), and purple (410 nm, 2 H9/2 → 4 I15/2) emission of Er 3+ to overall UCL are discussed as well as n values and decay kinetics.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Simulation of the influence of the excitation beam profile (BP) on UC(P) and n(P).
As a first step to quantitative UCL measurements at broadly varied P, we assessed the influence of BP on UC(P) with the aid of simulations. To consider BP-dependent effects, eq. 3 was modified to yield UC as function of the local distribution of the excitation power PBP(x,y,z), see eq. 5. As representative BPs for the simulation a Top Hat (TH,exp) and Gaussian (Gauss,exp) BP were used, which were experimentally realized
with our setup (see Supporting Information (SI), Fig. S1 and S2), as well as an ideal Top Hat (TH,ideal) BP.
ϕ UC (𝑃BP) =
∭ 𝑃BP(𝑥,𝑦,𝑧) 𝜙UC,sat
𝑃balance 𝑃BP(𝑥,𝑦,𝑧)
+1 d𝑥d𝑦d𝑧
∞ −∞
∭ 𝑃BP(𝑥,𝑦,𝑧) d𝑥d𝑦d𝑧 ∞
−∞
(eq. 5)
Subsequently, UC(PBP) was calculated for UC,sat = 50 % and Pbalance = 1 Wcm -2 as detailed in the SI (see Fig. S3 and eq. S1 and S2). Beam deformation due to absorption in the sample volume was not considered as this is negligible for an absorption < 10 %. The results are highlighted in Fig. 1 (panel a)). Panel b) of Fig. 1 illustrates the quotients resulting for the different UC(PBP), i.e., UC(PGauss,exp)/UC(PTH,ideal), UC(PGauss,exp)/UC(PTH,exp), and UC(PTH,exp)/UC(PTH,ideal)). The relatively close match between UC(PTH,exp) and UC(PTH,ideal) with deviations of maximally 13 % suggests a rather homogeneous P distribution for TH,exp and highlights the suitability of our setup design for the quantitative characterization of UC materials. A Gaussian BP leads to an overestimation of UC, yielding values that exceed the corresponding UC(PTH,ideal) and UC(PTH,exp) data by about 50 % and 30 %, respectively. These deviations are most pronounced in the unsaturated P-regime.
n(𝑃BP) = 𝑑 log (𝐼UC(𝑃BP))/𝑑 log(𝑃), (eq. 6)
The P-dependent slope factors n(P) of the different UCL bands were determined with eq. 6. As follows from panel c) of Fig. 1, n(P) can be divided into an unsaturated and a saturated P regime with constant slope values of 2 and 1, and a semisaturated regime reflected by a steady reduction of n from 2 approaching 1 for saturation. BP-dependent effects are observed only in the semi-saturated P-regime. (see Fig. 1, panel c)) Moreover, Fig. 1 demonstrates that n(Pbalance) obtained for TH,ideal. equals 1.5 whereas for an inhomogeneous BP like Gauss,exp, n(Pbalance) deviates obviously from 1.5. These findings clearly underline the considerable impact of the homogeneity of the P distribution on resulting UC(P) and n(P).

sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx Nanoscale., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Figure 1. a) Simulation of UC(PTH,ideal) (black line), UC(PTH,exp) (blue line), and UC(PGauss,exp) (red line) with UC,sat = 50 % and Pbalance = 1 Wcm -2 for a path length of 10 mm assuming a
biphotonic optical transition. b) Quotients of UC(PTH,exp)) and UC(PTH,ideal) (cyan line) and UC(PGauss,exp) and UC(PTH,ideal) (orange line), respectively. For comparison with our actual measurements shown in Fig. 2, we also included the quotient of UC(PGauss,exp)) and UC(PTH,exp) (violet line). c) Corresponding n(P) for a biphotonic optical transition like the green emission obtained for the three BPs with eq. 6.
Influence of beam profile on UC, n, and UCL intensity ratios for dispersed UCNP.
We subsequently assessed the P-dependence of UC, n, and the corresponding intensities IUC(em,P) of the green (520, 540 nm, 2 H11/2, 4 S3/2 → 4 I15/2), red (655 nm, 4 F9/2 → 4 I15/2), and purple (410 nm, 2 H9/2→ 4 I15/2) UCL of Er 3+ (given as spectral photon fluxes (s -1 m -3 )) for the TH,exp and Gauss,exp BPs. As follows from Fig. 2 (panels a) and b)), with deviations in the order of 20-30%, UC(PTH,exp) and UC(PGauss,exp) agree reasonably well with the results of our simulations (see Fig. 1, panel b)). It has to be taken into account here that this comparison is only qualitative, since our determination of the UC values of the UCNP also includes the intensity of triphotonic emission bands. Fitting of UC(P) of the purely biphotonic green emission yields UC,sat,green of 1 % with Pbalance of 550 Wcm -2 , see SI (Fig. S4 and Table S2; deviation of maximum 10 %). A possible explanation for the increasing deviation of measured and simulated UC(P) data for P > 1000 Wcm -2 (see SI, Fig. S4, left panel) can be the more pronounced contribution of triphotonic processes for the Gauss,exp BP. Also particle-to-particle variations in size, dopant ion concentration, and number of lattice and surface defects can lead to a distribution of particles with different UC and Pbalance especially for small UCNP with a high surfaceto-volume ratio as discussed e.g., for semiconductor quantum dots. 43, 44 In the case of NaYF4: Yb 3+ , Er 3+ UCNPs, main contributions to UC(P) in the order of at least 70% arise from the green and red emission. A closer look at the integral emission intensities
of the different UCL bands IUC(em), given in percentage of the overall integral UCL intensity UC(all); see Fig. 2, panel c), shows almost identical trends (deviation < 10 %) for TH,exp and Gauss,exp BPs despite the different photonic orders of the green and red emission. 23, 45 Contrary, the intensity of the triphotonic purple emission reveals a more pronounced increase for Gauss,exp compared to TH,exp BP. This is ascribed to the higher P near the focal point for the former BP. For our UCNP, the green emission is most pronounced at low P values up to 20 Wcm -2 in the unsaturated P regime, accounting for about 42 % of the overall UCL. Upon onset of UC saturation in the high P regime, the contribution of the green emission decreases to 27 % whereas the red emission becomes more pronounced, rising from initially 30 % at low P to 55 % in the saturated P regime of about P > 2000 Wcm -2 . This underlines the potential of varying P for color tuning. The change in the red-to-green intensity ratio (Ig/r) (see Fig. S6) in the P regime of 10-2000 Wcm -2 is ascribed to back energy transfer (BET) from Er 3+ to Yb 3+ , with the red emission band ( 4 F9/2 - 4 I15/2 transition) being efficiently populated from the 4 G11/2-level. 45 Our observation that the intensity of the red emission converges at about 1000 Wcm -2 while the purple emission still increases steadily suggests prevention of BET between the 4 G11/2→ 4 F9/2 transition of Er 3+ and the 2 F5/2 → 2 F7/2 transition of Yb 3+ for saturation.

sections.heading: ARTICLE Nanoscale
sections.text:
4 | Nanoscale., 2017, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Figure 2. a) UC(P) of NaYF4:Er 3+Yb3+ UCNP dispersed in toluene measured with TH,exp (open squares) and Gauss,exp BPs (open triangles) using an optical path length of 10 mm and integrating over all UC emission bands between 370 and 890 nm). b) Quotient of UC(P) obtained with Gauss,exp and TH,exp BPs; c) P-dependent integral intensities of the purple (410 nm; purple square symbols, green (sum of both green emission bands at 520 nm and 540 nm: light green circles), and red emission bands (655 nm; red triangles) of Er3+ given in percentage of the total UCL for our UCNP measured with TH,exp (full symbols) and Gauss,exp BP (open symbols); d) and e) corresponding slope factors n(PTH,exp) (full symbols) and n(PGauss,exp) (open symbols) for the different emission bands of Er 3+ (violet: 410 nm, dark cyan: 520 nm, dark green: 540 nm, and red: 655 nm). The P-dependent slope factors of the 520 nm and 540 nm emission band overlap.
Panels d) and e) of Fig. 2 summarize the n(P) values obtained with TH,exp and Gauss,exp BPs (calculation of n(P) from experimental data as detailed in the SI (see Fig. S7 and eq. S4). These panels highlight the small differences between both experimentally obtained data sets of maximally 10 % and the decrease of n(P) of all emission bands with increasing P indicating saturation. For the unsaturated P-regime (P < 10 Wcm -2 ), n amounts to 2 for the green and the red emission and to 3 for the purple emission, respectively. This points to similar population pathways of the green and the red luminescence at low P. At P = 50 Wcm -2 , the red emission shows a maximum n value of 2.2 suggesting contributions from bi- and triphotonic processes due to increased population of the 4 G11/2 energy level, which feeds also the triphotonic purple emission 40 . Recycling of photons via BET to Yb 3+ is unlikely, since Yb 3+ quenching is high particularly for unshelled and relatively small UCNPs as studied here. Recently, Berry et al. demonstrated for 90 nm-sized particles that the red emission is mostly fed by a triphotonic process even at low P. 45 Our n values suggest, however, that in the case of smaller UCNP like our 25 nm sized UCNPs, a biphotonic population process of the red emission is dominant at low P. P-dependence of luminescence spectra, UC, and slope factors of nm and µm-sized UC powders. Subsequently, we studied the UCL of our UCNP in the solid state and commercial µm-sized UC particles (UCµP) of comparable degree of doping using the TH,exp BP to assess size effects without the contribution of potentially quenching solvent molecules. This enables also a comparison with results from Boyer and van Veggel 32 and theoretical data of UC(P) reported for UCµP by the Berry group. 23 UC(P), IUC, and n values resulting for the different UCL bands are summarized in Fig. 3.

sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx Nanoscale., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 5
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Figure 3. P-dependence of a) UC of NaYF4:Er 3+,Yb3+ UCNP powder and a commercial UCµP powder measured with TH,exp and an optical path length of 0.1 mm; the UC data of UCµP were corrected for the beam deformation due to heated ND filters and the Yb3+ emission at the excitation wavelength41 (see SI, Fig.S5 and S8); b) Quotient of UC(P) of UCNP and UCµP; c) P-dependent integral intensities of the purple (410 nm; purple squares) green (sum of both green emission bands at 520 nm and 540 nm: light green circles), and red emission bands (655 nm; red triangles) given in percentage of total UCL for solid UCNP (open symbols) and UCµP (full symbols), respectively. d) and e) Corresponding slope factors n(P) derived for solid UCNP (open symbols) and UCµP (full symbols) for the different emission bands of Er3+ (violet: 410 nm, dark cyan: 520 nm, dark green: 540 nm, and red: 655 nm) with TH,exp BP. n(P) of the 520 nm and 540 nm emission bands overlap for solid UCNP; for UCµP, the corresponding n reveal a different P-dependence for P > 15 Wcm-2.
As follows from Fig. 3 (panel a)), UC(P) of the UCNP powder increases steadily up to P values of 46 Wcm -2 , where the material started to degrade, most likely due to decomposition of the organic surface ligands. UC(P) of the UCµP powder increases with increasing P and levels off at P of about 30 Wcm -2
. Fitting of UC(P) of the green emission yields
UC,sat,green of 0.6 % with Pbalance of 100 Wcm -2 , see SI (Fig. S3 and Table S2; deviation < 5 %). The decrease in UC(P) of the UCµP powder at higher P exceeding the saturation power is not to be expected from the balancing power model, yet can be simulated with actual rate equation models currently developed. This observation is attributed to the larger proportion of absorbed photons used for triphotonic UC processes at high P. 45
Although UC(P) of the UCNP and UCµP
powders differ by more than two orders of magnitude at low P, these deviations strongly decrease with increasing P (see also Fig. 3, panel b)). This strong diminution of UC(P) with particle size is reflected by the decay kinetics of the Yb 3+ emission at 976 nm ( 2 F5/2→ 2 F7/2) and the green emission of Er 3+ (540 nm, 4 S3/2 → 4 I15/2) and NIR (1520), yielding reductions in lifetime by factors of 17,6 and 3, respectively (see Fig. 4, Fig. S9
and Table S3). This shows, that the main contribution of the UC reduction results from Yb 3+ quenching revealed by Würth et al. and Arppe et al., 40, 46 while the Er 3+ decays is much less affected. This is ascribed to quenching of UCL by (CH2)n stretching vibrational modes of the oleate ligands at 2800 to 2950 cm -1 , 47 that overlap with the energy level differences of several emission bands like the green and red luminescence which are in the order of 3000 cm -1 to 3200 cm - 1 . 47
.Comparison of UC(P) of the UCNP powder and the corresponding UCNP dispersion (see SI, Fig. S10) highlights the reduction in UC(P) by factors of about 4 for low P (P of about 1 Wcm -2 ) and 3 at higher P (P of about 30 Wcm -2 ) for dispersed UCNP; this reflects additional surface quenching by solvent molecules. This is supported by the lifetime data of the Yb 3+ ( 2 F5/2→ 2 F7/2) transition (see SI Fig. S9 panel d)), which also underlines the difficulties of finding suitable rate constants for the modelling with rate equations, since the beginning of the decay curve of UCNP powder is strongly multiexponential.

sections.text:
6 | Nanoscale., 2017, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Figure 4 a) Energy scheme of the NIR emission of Yb 3+ at 976 nm and Er 3+ at 1520 nm, respectively;. b) Decay curves of the directly excited Yb 3+ emission ( 2 F5/2→ 2 F7/2) at 976 nm (detected at exc = 940 nm) obtained for UCµP (blue) and UCNP (black) powders and UCNP dispersed in toluene (red); c) Rise and decay of the Er 3 + emission at 1520 nm ( 4 I13/2→ 4 I15/2) for exc = 976 nm measured with a short laser pulse (pulse width < 2 µs), same colour code as used for panel b).
As follows from Fig. 3 (panel a)) and Table S1, we obtained UC,max of 10.5 % (integration over all emission bands) for the UCµP powder at P = 30 Wcm -2 , equaling a value of 9.3 % for integration of only the visible (vis) luminescence, i.e., the purple, green, and red emission. For solely the green emission we measured 2.4 %, (P = 20 Wcm -2 , see Table 1), which is identical to the value from Page reported for bulk NaYF4: Er 3+ , Yb 3+ (it should be noted, that for direct comparison with our measurements, the value provided by Page had to be converted from power conversion efficiency to UC see SI, Figure S11; the power conversion efficiency takes the photon energy into account and can thus reach maximum 100 % whereas UC defined in eq. 2 can reach maximally 50 % for a purely biphotonic process and even lower values for higher order photonic processes). Our UC value agrees also well with the UC value of 3.0 +/- 0.3% obtained by van Veggel for the green emission of pure -phase 20 % Yb 3+ , 2% Er 3+- doped NaYF4 UCµP with a size >> 100 nm 34 at identical P. Our overall UC values agree also well with simulations of UC(P) of commercial -phase NaYF4: 18 % Yb 3+ , 2 % Er 3+ UCµP of the Berry group obtained from coupled rate equations 23 (Fig. 5) utilizing lifetime data and spectral data measured with pulsed excitation (varied from 2 to 200 mJ/cm²). This yields UC,max of 7.6 % for the visible UCL derived from the sum of the purple, green, and red emission. Interestingly, contrary to this generally good agreement, the UC values obtained for the individual UC bands differ strongly from simulations of the Berry group, although the rise and decay kinetics of the purple, green and red emission, (see SI, Fig. S12) of our UCµP closely match with the lifetime data reported by the Berry group, underpinning the comparability of both materials.
Figure 5 Comparison of experimentally determined UC of the visible emission (black symbols) derived from the sum of the purple (purple symbols), green (green symbols), and red UC (red symbols) with the results from the simulation of these quantities of the Berry group (corresponding lines).
Fig. 3 (panel c)) shows a comparison of the relative integral intensities of the different UC emission bands of our UCµP and UCNP powders. This underlines the influence of particle size on the intensity ratios of the green and red emission (Ig/r), which present the main contributions to UC(P) with >80 % and >75 %, respectively. For UCµP, Ig/r increases with decreasing P, whereas for UCNP, which are more prone to nonradiative depopulation processes, Ig/r converges to 1.25 for decreasing P (see SI, Fig. S6). This underlines the lower nonradiative rate from the green to the red band for UCµP. In the saturated regime for both materials the Ig/r converges to 0.33 and 0.5 for UCµP and UCNP, respectively. Ig/r values < 1 for high P have
been previously reported. In general, for high P, a Ig/r value of 0.3 to 0.4 value is often obtained for NaYF4–based systems with doping concentrations of about 20 % of Yb 3+ and 2 % of Er 3+
, which suggests that this Ig/r value may be specific for UCL
saturation. 31, 48, 49 This was also recently found by us for 23 nmsized NaYF4 UCNPs with these doping concentrations. 40 Additionally it was demonstrated that for the same UCNP material in different environments the population dynamics are comparable for high P despite different quenching rates. 40 In case of the triphotonic purple emission also the population for the UCµP is more effective as reflected by a higher

sections.text:

percentage of its contribution to the overall UCL (see Fig. 3, panel c)); this is ascribed to the longer lifetimes of the Er 3+ intermediate energy levels of the UCµP powder (see also SI, section on luminescence dynamics). n(P) of the green, red, and purple emission bands of the UCNP and UCµP powders are highlighted in panels d) and e) of Fig. 3. For the UCNP powder, we obtained n of two for the green and red emission in the unsaturated P regime and n of 2.5 for the purple emission, respectively. The latter falls below the n value of 3 obtained in UCNP dispersion. In the case of the UCµP powder, n(P) of all emission bands decrease with increasing P as to be expected for saturation. Comparison of the n(P) values

derived for all UC emission bands of the UCµP powder in the saturation regime reveals that solely the 520 nm emission ( 2 H11/2→ 4 I15/2) converges to 1, whereas n(P) of the other emission bands reach a value of about 0.5 for P of 100 Wcm -2 . Although the 2 H11/2 state can be thermally populated from the 4 S3/2 state according to the Boltzmann population, 50 this cannot account for the trend of n(P) of the 520 nm emission, since additionally performed longterm illumination studies show a minimal influence on UC intensity < 5 % for high P (see SI, Fig. S13).

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we presented strategies for the quantitative determination of excitation power density (P)-dependent upconversion (UC) luminescence (UCL) spectra and intensity ratios and UC quantum yields UC(P) of nanoparticle dispersions and solid samples and other spectroscopic parameters like slope factors (n) relevant for mechanistic insights in UC processes. Moreover, ligand and solvent quenching were quantified and the potential of P for tuning UC efficiency and color underlined. Although the UC value found by us for UC microparticles differs from the value reported by van Veggel 32 for a similar material of yet unknown dopant concentration, the good agreement of our UC(P) with UC(P) simulated by the Berry group 45 validates our measurements. Despite the generally good match for the combined visible
emission, our results suggest an overestimation of the purple and an underestimation of the red emission of -NaYF4:Yb 3+ , Er 3+ : microparticles by the simulations of the Berry group. Our P-dependent UCL measurements with different beam profiles underline that the main factors rendering the comparability of reported UC values presently critical are the strong influence of the size, shape, and homogeneity of the spatial P distribution on UCL and UC together with the challenge to reliably measure P. This makes also relative measurements of UC suggested in some publications 5 very error prone. The considerably different UC values of dispersed and solid UCNP in the low P regime underpin the importance of measurements of UC(P) for comparison of UC efficiencies of UC materials. This renders maximal UC (UC,max) values better suited for straightforward material performance assessment.

sections.heading: Materials and methods
sections.text:
Materials. 25 nm-sized -NaYF4:Yb 3+ : 17 %, Er 3+ : 3% UCNPs (crystallite size 23x26-30 nm) were prepared through coprecipitation in a binary solvent mixture of oleic acid and 1- octadecene 14 and characterized by TEM and XRD (see Fig. S14). Luminescence measurements were performed with these oleate-stabilized UCNP dispersed in toluene and as dried powder. 3 µm-sized -NaYF4: Yb 3+ , Er 3+ particles doped with ca.

sections.heading: ARTICLE Nanoscale
sections.text:
8 | Nanoscale., 2017, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
21.4 % Yb 3+ and 2.2 % Er 3+ (PTIR 550) 42 were obtained from Phosphor Technology Ltd. and measured as powder. Absorption measurements. Absorption spectra of the UCNP dispersions were recorded on a calibrated Cary 5000 spectrometer. As follows from an absorption spectrum of the UCNP dispersed in toluene shown in the SI (Fig. S2), these dispersions are nonscattering at the excitation wavelength. Absolute measurement of P-dependent UC. P-dependent UC values were obtained absolutely with a custom designed integrating sphere setup previously reported, 51 modified to meet the requirements of UC luminescence measurements like the use of a high stability 8 W 976 nm laser diode as excitation light source. More details on the calibration of the setup, beam profile characterization, measurement procedure and evaluation of the data are given in the SI (see Section on Integrating sphere setup for absolute measurements of UC) Time-resolved luminescence measurements. Lifetime measurements of the UC and downconverted (DC) luminescence (downshifted or Stokes shifted emission upon direct excitation of the respective emitter) were done with a Edinburgh Instruments spectrofluorometer FSP-920 equipped with an electrically pulsed 1 W 978 nm laser diode (950 ms long square pulse), a pulsed xenon lamp (pulse width ca. 1 µs), a red extended PMT (R2658P; UC luminescence), and a NIR PMT (R5509P; DC luminescence) from Hamamatsu (see SI, Fig. S9 and Table S3). For the comparison of the lifetime data of the berry group 23 and for the control of the reliability of the resulting lifetimes of the long pulse measurements the luminescence decays obtained with short pulse (~10 ns) excitation performed at TU Berlin using a dye (IR140) laser pumped with an excimer laser. The observed deviations were < 10 %. More details and the resulting lifetimes are provided in the SI (Figure S9 and Table S3 and S4). The decay analysis is detailed in the SI (see Section on Method for the determination of the lifetime components).

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We gratefully acknowledge Emilia Palo for the synthesis of the upconversion nanoparticles, fruitful discussions with Dr. Markus Grabolle, Prof. Dr. Axel Hoffmann for enabling timeresolved measurements with short pulse excitation in his lab. Financial support from the Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology (MNPQ program, projects BMWI-13/09 and BMWI-11/12), the German Research Council (DFG; grant RE1203/18-1), and the European Upconversion Network (COST Action CM1403) is gratefully acknowledged.
